0.21.text:
What would you say if we told you
that humanity is currently making

3.52.text:
a collaborative effort to
engineer the perfect superbug?

7.36.text:
A bug that could kill hundreds
of millions of people?

10.63.text: Well, it is happening right now.

13.62.text:
We are in the process
of creating a superbacterium.

26.21.text:
Bacteria are among the oldest
living things on this planet.

29.61.text:
The smallest thing we still consider life,
they are masters of survival

35.67.text: Most bacteria are harmless to us.

37.85.text:
Your body hosts trillions of them,
and they help you to survive.

41.81.text:
But others can invade your body,
spread quickly, and kill you.

45.77.text:
Millions of people used to die as a result
of bacterial infections.

53.05.text:
Together with vaccinations, antibiotics
revolutionized medicine

58.77.text:
Antibiotics kill the vast majority of
susceptible bacteria fairly quickly,

62.86.text: leaving only a small group of survivors

64.76.text:
that our immune system
then deals with easily.

69.96.text:
Imagine a bacterium as
a very complex machine

72.55.text:
with thousands of complex processes
going on that keep it alive and active.

79.85.text:
for example, by
interfering with its metabolism,

82.49.text:
slowing down their growth significantly,
so they are less of a threat.

86.70.text:
Other antibiotics attack DNA
and prevent it from being replicated,

90.28.text:
which stops bacteria from multiplying,
ultimately killing them.

94.08.text:
Or by simply ripping the outer layer
of the bacteria to shreds,

97.38.text:
so that their insides spill
out and they die quickly.

100.69.text: All of this without bothering body cells.

103.94.text:
But now, evolution is making
things more complicated.

108.08.text:
By pure random chance, a small minority
of the bacteria invading your body

112.45.text:
might have evolved a way
to protect themselves.

115.53.text:
For example, by intercepting
the antibiotics

117.79.text:
and changing the molecule
so it becomes harmless.

120.88.text:
Or by investing energy in pumps
that eject the antibiotics

126.69.text:
A few immune bacteria
are not that big a deal,

129.08.text:
because the immune system
can take care of them.

131.99.text:
But if they escape, they
might spread their immunity.

138.25.text:
First of all, bacteria
have two kinds of DNA:

141.00.text:
the chromosome and small
free-floating parts called plasmids.

145.37.text:
They can hug each other
and exchange those plasmids

150.82.text:
This way, immunity can be
spread quickly through a population.

154.40.text:
Or, in a process called transformation,
bacteria can harvest dead bacteria

160.59.text:
This even works between
different bacteria species

163.12.text:
and can lead to superbugs, bacteria
that are immune to multiple antibiotics.

168.95.text:
A variety of superbugs
already exist in the world.

172.24.text:
Especially hospitals are the
perfect breeding grounds for them.

178.24.text:
The horrors of the pre-antibiotic
era have been forgotten.

181.73.text:
Today, we treat this powerful medicine
as a commodity

184.65.text:
instead of as the game-changing
achievement of science that it is.

189.10.text: This has led to a strange disconnect:

191.06.text:
hundreds of millions of people
still don’t have access

195.79.text:
while in other parts of the world
antibiotics are prescribed too freely

201.89.text: Antibiotics should be a last-resort drug,

204.27.text:
not something you take
because your cold is annoying.

207.71.text:
Another serious problem is
antibiotic use in meat production.

212.20.text:
At any particular point in time,
humanity holds

214.76.text:
between 20 and 30 billion
animals as livestock.

218.42.text:
To make meat cheaper, many animals
are held in horrible conditions,

221.93.text:
in very tight spaces, and
in unhygienic conditions,

225.31.text: the perfect breeding ground for disease.

229.06.text:
So many animals are given antibiotics
to kill as many bacteria as possible

232.93.text: and prevent them from getting sick.

234.94.text:
Because a cheeseburger
has to cost a dollar.

237.61.text:
Unsurprisingly, as a
result of this system,

239.93.text:
we have created
more and more bacteria

244.81.text:
To counteract this, we
use different antibiotics

247.23.text:
and we have another secret weapon:
there are specific antibiotics

251.71.text:
that are used to wipe out bacteria
that have developed resistance.

255.08.text:
There are strict rules for using these
to avoid the creation of a superbacterium.

262.26.text:
In late 2015, scary news
arrived from China.

266.01.text:
Resistance against Colistin,
a last-ditch antibiotic,

270.62.text:
Colistin is an old drug and was rarely
used, because it can damage the liver.

274.72.text:
So there was little resistance against it,
which made it a great

277.89.text:
antibiotic of last resort for certain
complex infections that occur in hospitals

282.45.text:
to fight bacteria that have become immune
to a whole bunch of other drugs.

286.65.text:
Bacteria resistance to Colistin
is very, very bad news.

290.82.text:
It might destroy a last line of defense
and lead to a whole lot of dead people.

297.25.text:
Millions of animals in Chinese pig farms
have been given Colistin for years.

301.13.text:
Resistant bacteria developed, spreading
first from animal to animal,

304.35.text: and then to humans without being noticed.

307.26.text:
On an average day, there are
over 100,000 flights on Earth,

310.93.text:
kind of connecting every
human on the planet.

314.02.text:
By creating the modern world,
we have also built the infrastructure

319.79.text: Still, we don’t need to panic just yet.

322.25.text:
Bacteria evolve, humans do research,
new antibiotics are developed

326.80.text:
as old ones become obsolete,
technology is advancing every day.

331.33.text:
The problem is real and serious,
but the fight is far from over.
